Kevin Chu

PhD Candidate in Materials Science | Georgia Tech

Email: kchu41@gatech.edu

About Me

I study fundamental deformation and strengthening mechanisms at the nano and mesoscale to inform the design of alloys. I leverage existing codebases and implement novel computational approaches as necessary to enhace predictive simulation capabilities. Skills honed during my PhD include:

  • Molecular Dynamics/Monte Carlo methods (LAMMPS)
  • Concurrent Atomistic-Continuum multiscale modeling (CAC)
  • Data analysis and visualization (Scipy, Jupyter, Pandas)
  • Scientific software development (MPI, Fortran90, C++)
  • Scripting and automation (Python, BASH)

Education

Georgia Institute of Technology

PhD Materials Science and Engineering

2017 - 2022

PhD Advisors - David L. McDowell & Ting Zhu

University of California, Los Angeles

B.S. Materials Science and Engineering

2013 - 2017

Undergraduate Advisor - Jaime Marian

Research Experience

Georgia Institute of Technology

Graduate Research Assistant

August 2017 - Present

  • Identified the link between average-atom EAM potentials and concurrent atomistic-continuum (CAC) coarse-grained models, designed and executed validation simulations
  • Contributed to open-source fork of LAMMPS codebase to implement necessary features for finite-temperature alloy simulations
  • Collaborated with national labs and various university research partners to paint a cohesive picture of deformation in additively-manufactured 316L stainless steels

U.S. Naval Research Laboratory

NREIP Graduate Fellowship

Summer 2021

  • Selected for Naval Research Enterprise Intern Program (NREIP) at the US Naval Research Lab.
  • Designed efficient large-scale Monte-Carlo (MC) annealing algorithms to develop short-range solute ordering in complex alloy systems.
  • Created a Python-based workflow to process both atom-probe tomography datasets and MC-computed microstructures to directly quantify cluster size and distributions.

Sandia National Laboratories

R&D Graduate Intern

Summer 2019

  • Designed rastering algorithm for computing interstitial and substitutional solute site binding energies
  • Executed large scale parametric dislocation mobility simulations and analyses in 3XX stainless steels
  • Theorized and implemented a continuum-scale diffusion model for Cottrell atomosphere formation kinetics.

Sandia National Laboratories

R&D Undergraduate Intern

Summer 2017

  • Designed and executed molecular dynamics simulations of epitaxially grown crystalline materials using LAMMPS and high performance computing clusters.
  • Discovered correlation between surface pitting defects and interface dislocation nucleation.

Publications

(2022) Multiscale Concurrent Atomistic-Continuum (CAC) modeling of multicomponent alloys

K. Chu, A. Diaz, Y. Chen, T. Zhu, and D. L. McDowell, Computational Materials Science, 201 (2022).

https://doi.org/10.1016/j.commatsci.2021.110873

(2020) Temperature and composition dependent screw dislocation mobility in austenitic stainless steels from large-scale molecular dynamics

K. Chu, M. E. Foster, R. B. Sills, X. Zhou, T. Zhu, and D. L. McDowell, npj Computational Materials, 6(1) (2020).

https://doi.org/10.1038/s41524-020-00452-x

(2020) Molecular Statics Analyses of Thermodynamics and Kinetics of Hydrogen Cottrell Atmosphere Formation Around Edge Dislocations in Aluminum

C. D. Spataru, K. Chu, R. B. Sills, and X. Zhou, JOM, 72(8) (2020).

https://doi.org/10.1007/s11837-020-04213-5

(2018) Molecular dynamics studies of InGaN growth on nonpolar (11-20) GaN surfaces

K. Chu, J. Gruber, X. W. Zhou, R. E. Jones, S. R. Lee, and G. J. Tucker, Phys. Rev. Materials, 2(1) (2018).

https://doi.org/10.1103/PhysRevMaterials.2.013402

(2017) Polymorphic improvement of Stillinger-Weber potential for InGaN

X. W. Zhou, R. E. Jones, and K. Chu, Journal of Applied Physics, 122(23), (2017).

https://doi.org/10.1063/1.5001339
